content.statement: An endofunctor is a functor from a category to itself (F: C→C), mapping objects and morphisms within the same category. All monads are endofunctors.

explanation.intuition: An endofunctor is a 'self-transformation' of a category - it maps objects and morphisms back into the same category. Think of reshaping data while staying in the same universe of types. Most functors in programming are endofunctors.
explanation.key_insight: Endofunctors are crucial for monads because monads require composition of a functor with itself (F∘F), which only makes sense for endofunctors. This is why 'a monad is a monoid in the category of endofunctors'.
explanation.technical_details: An endofunctor F: C→C maps C to itself. For types, List: Types→Types is an endofunctor (maps Int to List<Int>, etc.). Endofunctors can be composed (F∘G is an endofunctor if F and G are), enabling monad structure.

formal_definition.latex: \text{Endofunctor: } F: \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C} \\ \text{where source and target categories are identical}

examples.description: Maps each set to its power set
Nearly all type constructors are endofunctors

significance: Required for monad definition (monads are endofunctors with unit and join)
Form a category themselves (category of endofunctors)
Most functors in programming are endofunctors on Types

connection_to_monads.statement: A monad is an endofunctor M: C→C equipped with natural transformations η: Id→M (unit) and μ: M∘M→M (join)
connection_to_monads.why_endofunctor: We need M∘M (M applied twice) to make sense, requiring M: C→C

sources.citation: Mac Lane, S. (1971). Categories for the Working Mathematician. Springer.

cross_domain_references.note: This programming concept APPLIES mathematical concepts from their native domains

applies.applicationContext: Endofunctors are functors from a category to itself, foundational to monads
